nav.div: Seattle Public Schools » Our District » Calendars and News » News » What's New » Coronavirus Update

div.div: COVID-19 Updates and Resources for Families and Students

img.title: District logo with text "Covid-19 Updates"
img.h2: All Schools Closed Through End of the School Year
img.p: On Monday, April 6, 2020, Governor Inslee made an emergency proclamation extending the closure of all schools through the end of the 2019-20 school year.

div.p: To translate please use the Google "Select Language" at the top of this webpage. Resources for English Language Learners: Amharic Chinese Somali Spanish Tagalog Vietnamese

li.a: Resources for families including student meals

a.title: skip down to the learning ideas
skip down to most recent letter

li.a: Most recent letter to the Seattle Public Schools community

a.title: open the document. opens a new tab
open the document. opens a new tab
open the document. opens a new tab
open the document. opens a new tab
open the document. opens a new tab

img.p: Welcome back from spring break. We hope that your family found ways to connect and find joy during this challenging time. While our school buildings are closed, our staff are working hard to ensure students are supported and learning continues. Your family's wellbeing centers all our decisions. In today's communication you can learn about the district's approach to grades during school closure, special education supports, next year's school choice assignments, high school updates, and supports for combating racism in our community. You may also find a growing list of general school closure FAQs.

Today, the school board voted to temporarily suspend portions of the district's high school grading policy so that students taking high school courses will receive either an "A" or an "Incomplete" for the duration of the COVID-19 related school closure. This change applies to all high school students, including those receiving specialized services. Several grading options were analyzed using the district's racial equity tool including a review of student case studies. While there is no perfect solution, the A/I grading option recognizes the challenges faced by all students and intentionally minimizes harm for students furthest away from educational justice.

To receive an "A", students will engage to the extent possible in activities or learning provided and make progress towards grade-level standards. Making "A" the only credit-based grade will ensure students, especially students furthest from educational justice, are not harmed as a result of their circumstances or inequitable access. In addition, to encourage students' engagement in learning, educators will have the option to give "Incompletes" to students who had the ability to engage but did not. Incompletes will be carefully monitored by school leaders and every effort to engage students in learning will be made. Students who receive an "Incomplete" will have an option to appeal this decision and will be able to complete work through summer and fall semesters of 2020. If progress is demonstrated, a student's transcript will be adjusted to reflect an "A." Per a new state law, seniors are also eligible for emergency waivers for any credits they had planned to earn by February 29.

ul.li: More information on these waivers can be found on our Class of 2020 FAQ page.
More information on high school grades during school closures is available in the High School Grading FAQ.

img.p: Middle school students will receive a "P" for passing. They will be asked to remain engaged in the standards-based activities or learning assigned by their teacher(s) to the greatest extent possible. Middle school students taking courses for high school credit will receive an "A" if they remain engaged in the standards-based activities or learning assigned by their teacher(s) to the extent possible, or an "I" (for incomplete). Incompletes can be made up anytime through the first semester of 2020-21. More information about the A/I grading options for high school courses is available in the High School Grading FAQ.
Additional guidance for the Elementary Trimester 3 grade marking period will be released soon.

p.strong: Grading changes are only for Spring Semester 2020. Further board action will be required if school is closed beyond the 2019-20 school year.

img.p: Learning plans will be developed to support continuous learning for students with IEPs. The learning plans will be used to support work accommodations and supports for coursework completion in consultation with staff and families who know the student best.

Beginning tomorrow, April 21, the Assignment Lookup Tool will be available for families to look up their school assignment for the 2020-21 school year, including Open Enrollment for School Choice results. A direct communication will be sent to families this week who applied for School Choice.

p.strong: Additional Information for High School Students and Families

img.p: We continue to rollout the distribution of laptops, prioritizing high school seniors who do not have access to another device in their home, and then continuing to students in grades 9-11. Your family will receive a school messenger call and email when a laptop is available for your child. Please remember that school staff has helped identify students who need a laptop. If your child needs one, contact the school or your child's counselor.

p.strong: Resources for Students to Help Prepare for the Advanced Placement Exam Online

img.p: The College Board continues to offer free "live" online AP Classes for students.

Beginning Monday, April 20, if a student does not plan to take an AP exam that has already been ordered, students and families can request a refund by completing the refund request form online no later than June 5. If families prefer a paper copy of this form, please contact your AP testing coordinator at your school and the form will be mailed to you through the US Postal Service. Refunds for AP exams will be processed after schools have access to the AP exams not taken. AP Testing Coordinators will not have access to see who completed the AP exam until after the makeup AP exam testing window in early June. More details on the High School FAQ page.

SPS is working with the State Board of Education and the School Board to give students additional flexibility around graduation requirements. Students who are eligible for waivers from specific graduation requirements will be contacted by their school counselors.

There continues to be a documented increase in racist anti-Asian hate incidents in our city. This is unacceptable. In SPS, we do not tolerate hate speech or acts of discrimination. Please help by reporting verbal harassment, discrimination, or hate crimes to the Seattle Office for Civil Rights at (206) 223-7100 or file a complaint online. Reports can also be submitted online to the Coronavirus Anti-AAPI Racism Incident Report to help build a national response. Responses can be anonymous, and reports can be made in English or in 11 different Asian languages.

We are committed to keeping you updated as new information becomes available. Family communications will be sent on Monday and Thursday each week until further notice. You may also find additional resources on the district homepage including food distribution sites, the most updated SPS TV broadcast of teacher led lessons, and childcare resources.

hr.h3: King County, Washington State, and National Health Resources
hr.p: The Washington State Department of Health has established a call center to address questions from the public. If you have questions about what is happening in Washington, or how the virus is spread, please call 1-800-525-0127.

Phone lines are currently staffed from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m, seven days a week. Please note that this call center can not access COVID-19 testing results. For testing inquiries or results, please contact your health care provider.

ul.li: 2019 Novel Coronavirus (2019 nCov), Public Health Seattle and King County (this site includes FAQ in English, Spanish and Chinese) Public Health provides frequent updates.
Please see the Washington State Department of Health's translated fact sheets.
Novel Coronavirus Outbreak 2020, Washington State Department of Health
2019 Novel Coronavirus, Wuhan, China, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

a.title: go to the CDC website. Open a new tab

li.a: Guidance for Travelers, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

hr.h3: Living our Values: Resources to combat racism, bias, and discrimination
hr.p: Our community values are tested in times like these. We must continue to be united and support each other as coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) becomes more widespread. In schools, we will continue to demonstrate compassion and care as our greater community navigates this global health situation.

We are aware of reports that some of our Asian students have been targeted and discriminated against in connection to COVID-19. This is unacceptable and contrary to our values of racial equity and social justice. In SPS, we are committed to welcoming, safe, and inclusive schools, and we do not tolerate hate speech or acts of discrimination.

Help us prevent discrimination or stigmatization by sharing accurate information. COVID-19 infection is not connected to any race, ethnicity, or nationality. Misinformation about coronavirus disease 2019 can create fear and hostility that harms people and makes it harder to keep everyone healthy. Public Health Seattle and King County has provided resources to address and prevent.
